item.title: Trump Says Kennedy Center Will Close for 2-Year Reconstruction Project
item.description: The president’s announcement came after the center has been rocked by cancellations and boycotts by performers, contributors and audience members.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Julia Jacobs
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers adding President Trump’s name to side of the Kennedy Center in Washington in December.

item.title: U.A.E. Firm Quietly Took Stake in the Trump Family’s Crypto Company
item.description: The $500 million agreement raises new concerns about the propriety of the president negotiating foreign policy with his own business partners.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Katarina Premfors for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zach Witkoff, left, and Eric Trump, speaking in Dubai in May. Eric Trump signed an agreement with an Emirati-backed investment firm days before his father’s inauguration in January 2025.

item.title: ‘Melania’ Arrives With Strong Box Office Showing for a Documentary
item.description: Amazon backed up the Brink’s trucks for the vanity film, resulting in weekend ticket sales of about $7 million in North America, enough for third place.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The first lady, Melania Trump, at a screening of “Melania” at the Kennedy Center in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Judge Who Ruled Against Trump Administration Cleared of Justice Dept. Complaint
item.description: Trump allies have called for Judge James E. Boasberg to be investigated and impeached after decisions that questioned the administration’s respect for the rule of law.
item.dc:creator: Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Judge James E. Boasberg in his chambers at the United States District Court for the District of Columbia last year.

item.title: Move Fast, but Obey the Rules: China’s Vision for Dominating A.I.
item.description: Beijing wants to lead the world in developing cutting-edge artificial intelligence, but it also wants companies to adhere to an increasingly complex set of rules.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan Tobin and Xinyun Wu
item.media:credit: Tommy Wang/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Executives at Zhipu AI, one of China’s most promising A.I. start-ups, alongside others, at a launch event at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange last month.

item.title: Can Tom Homan De-escalate ICE Tensions in Minnesota?
item.description: The White House border czar wants to focus more on getting immigrants already in jails. He’ll have to persuade Democrats to do it.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Homan, the border czar, at a news conference last week. After starting his career as a New York police officer, Mr. Homan spent decades in immigration enforcement, rising up to leadership roles.

item.title: Federal Courts Undercut Trump’s Mass Deportation Campaign
item.description: A policy intended to keep immigrants detained indefinitely has led to a deluge of lawsuits, overwhelming some federal courts and resulting in many releases.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan and Devlin Barrett
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times

item.title: How Alex Pretti’s Death Became a National Tipping Point
item.description: Several factors converged to force a remarkable shift in the federal government’s aggressive efforts in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Streeter
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners at the site where Alex Pretti was killed by federal agents, four days after the shooting.

item.title: How Trump Appears in the Epstein Files
item.description: The New York Times found more than 5,300 files with references to Mr. Trump and related terms. They include salacious and unverified claims, as well as documents that had already been made public.
item.dc:creator: Steve Eder, Michael C. Bender and David Enrich
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald Trump in the Oval Office on Friday.

item.title: The Government Published Dozens of Nude Photos in the Epstein Files
item.description: The photos, which showed young women or possibly teenagers with their faces visible, were largely removed after The New York Times began notifying the Justice Department.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Julie Tate
item.media:credit: U.S. Department of Justice
item.media:description: An undated photo of Jeffrey Epstein that was released by the Justice Department.

item.title: 2026 Grammys Takeaways: Bad Bunny and Kendrick Lamar Take Top Awards
item.description: On a night marked by explicit political statements, Bad Bunny became the first Spanish-language artist to win the ceremony’s top prize, while Kendrick Lamar is now the winningest rapper in Grammy history.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario
item.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images
item.media:description: Bad Bunny won album of the year at the 68th annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles on Sunday.

item.title: Unforgettable Grammys 2026 Looks: Chappell Roan, Sabrina Carpenter, Bad Bunny
item.description: Feathered gowns, sequined suits, freed nipples and more.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.media:credit: Mario Anzuoni/Reuters
item.media:description: Lady Gaga was one of many artists who embraced feathers at the Grammy Awards.

item.title: Grammys 2026 Winners List: Bad Bunny, Kendrick Lamar, Olivia Dean and More
item.description: A complete rundown of the artists, albums, songs and videos that took home trophies at the 68th annual awards.
item.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images
item.media:description: Kendrick Lamar accepted the Grammy for best rap album on Sunday night in Los Angeles.

item.title: Kehlani, Justin Bieber and More Wear ‘ICE Out’ Pins and Support Immigrants at Grammys
item.description: Bad Bunny joined Gloria Estefan, Shaboozey, Kehlani and others in speaking up for communities that are being targeted by ICE across the United States.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:credit: Neilson Barnard/Getty Images

item.title: Squeezed Between Trump and China, India Looks for Faraway Friendships
item.description: India is overcoming its aversion to free-trade deals to cozy up with Canada and other middle powers.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:credit: Sajjad Hussain/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, center, met with Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, and António Costa, the president of the European Council, in New Delhi in January.

item.title: The Secret Egyptian Air Base Powering Sudan’s Drone War
item.description: The covert base offers new evidence of how the Sudanese conflict is morphing into a theater for high-tech warfare, driven by foreign interests.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh, Malachy Browne, Eric Schmitt and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Satellite images by Vantor. The New York Times

item.title: N.Y. Republican in Swing District Gets Rowdy Reception at Town Hall
item.description: Representative Mike Lawler, who has promised to hold several town halls as he seeks re-election, was repeatedly heckled by audience members in Rockland County.
item.dc:creator: Jay Root and Nate Schweber
item.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Mike Lawler, a Hudson Valley Republican, is seeking a third term in a district newly rated a “tossup” by the Cook Political Report.

item.title: Democratic Upset in Deep Red Texas District Rattles Republicans
item.description: A Democrat won a state legislative special election in a district that President Trump carried by 17 percentage points, unnerving Republicans in Texas and beyond.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taylor Rehmet, a Democratic candidate for the Texas Senate, in Fort Worth in January.

item.title: Fear and Anger Grow as Thousands Remain Without Power in the South
item.description: More than 30 people have died across three Southern states in connection with last week’s storm, and thousands remain without power.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: George Walker Iv/Associated Press
item.media:description: Crews have been working for a week to restore power in Nashville and surrounding areas after an ice storm damaged the power grid.

item.title: A ‘Historic’ Snowfall Hits the Carolinas
item.description: Blanketed beaches. Frozen suburbs. Football fields buried in snow. Everywhere in the region, people felt the storm, which caused two deaths.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina

item.title: How a Village in Italy Became a Slice of Caracas
item.description: Generations of migrants from a village on the coast of southern Italy found a better life in Venezuela. Many came back and turned their town into a mini-Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Fabiola Ferrero

item.title: Physician Assistants Want a New Name and More Power. Not Everyone Is Happy.
item.description: How increased responsibilities and a push to be called “physician associates” are raising tensions with doctors.
item.dc:creator: Ben Blatt and Teddy Rosenbluth
item.media:credit: Amanda Lucier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Her name tag still says physician assistant, but in Oregon she’s known as a physician associate.

item.title: Physician Assistants Are Everywhere. Should You See One?
item.description: They wear white coats and do many things a doctor would do — and their numbers are increasing rapidly.
item.dc:creator: Teddy Rosenbluth

item.title: My Patient Was Dying. His Wife Would Not Accept It.
item.description: How doctors can better navigate difficult patients and families.
item.dc:creator: Daniela J. Lamas

item.title: Trump Has Overwhelmed Himself
item.description: This is a presidency that is, by any measure, failing.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Will Matsuda for The New York Times

item.title: Laura Fernández Wins Costa Rican Presidency
item.description: Laura Fernández’s victory was driven by a crisis in which Costa Rica’s reputation for peace has been tarred by record-breaking violence.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and David Bolaños
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laura Fernández, Costa Rica’s president-elect, celebrating her election victory alongside supporters on Sunday evening.

item.title: Oscar-Nominated Screenwriter Arrested in Iran for Criticizing Regime
item.description: Mehdi Mahmoudian, co-writer of “It Was Just an Accident,” was one of several people detained after signing a letter objecting to the crackdown on protests.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: The Yomiuri Shimbun, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mehdi Mahmoudian, a political activist and screenwriter, during an interview in Tehran in 2021.

item.title: Man and Dog Found Dead Inside Mobile Veterinary Van in Queens
item.description: A second man was found unconscious outside the van. The police are investigating whether the deaths were caused by carbon monoxide from a generator.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Southall and Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.media:credit: Miles Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The veterinary van where a man and a dog were found dead on Sunday morning in Queens. The police are investigating whether carbon monoxide fumes from a generator, pictured, played a role in the deaths.

item.title: Hazing Death in Arizona Leads to Charges for 3 Fraternity Leaders
item.description: Three 20-year-old students in Delta Tau Delta at Northern Arizona University were arrested on Saturday. The fraternity has been suspended.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:credit: Lacey Latch/The Republic/USA Today Network
item.media:description: The campus of Northern Arizona University in Flagstaff, Ariz.
